meeting_annotations.speaker: Gabriela Schlau-Cohen
meeting_annotations.transcript: I would just add on to that. I think there are two fundamental problems. One is the hidden variables problem which is what Masha brought up and then the second is a synchronization problem. So if you're measuring dynamics, if you can't control the synchronization, the cell is controlling it, you are inherently averaging over many stages of the enzymatic cycle.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker effectively builds on the previous point and introduces a new, related concept.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Neil Kelleher
meeting_annotations.transcript: So does does a single molecule approaches could does that change the synchronization calculus?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gabriela Schlau-Cohen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well the problem is that I think again we get back to a tool problem. With the single molecule aspect, you don't have the spatial resolution. If you're using an optical readout, you're essentially limited to the point spread function which is several hundred nanometers, the fundamental limit of light. And then there are some ways to get around that but those are very challenging to work with in sort of warm, wet, and noisy biological systems.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Neil Kelleher
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, so let's keep it on light as a readout. That's such that so many different assays are captured that way. Yeah so STORM or other super resolution approaches still couldn't get you to single molecule enzymology?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gabriela Schlau-Cohen
meeting_annotations.transcript: So here's the fundamental thing. Those sorts of single molecule those sorts of approaches are structural. You essentially assume a static structure, do a sequential build up bits of that structure through sequential images and then combine them to reconstruct the structure. It is a reconstruction method not an imaging method. But if you want to follow dynamics, you know, it's much much slower than like say a catalytic cycle. It looks at sort of slow structural rearrangements by building up a reconstruction.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alexis C Komor
meeting_annotations.transcript: I do some like in-cell enzymatic activity but I definitely in some ways I kind of cheat so that the sacrifice isn't really like I study DNA repair proteins. But yeah I was thinking about the readout and like for all of our assays the readout is fluorescence in some way and so we we usually use like flow cytometry to to look at fluorescence and that's like related back to to enzymatic activity. We don't do in vitro stuff because there's like 50 repair proteins that are all involved in a given pathway and so we can't like express and purify all of those. So that's why we like have to do it in the context of a cell. But then like our DNA substrate is one that we like made in a test tube and then put into the cell so it's not actually genomic DNA. And then people have issues with that. They're like it's not chromosomal, it's like not wrapped up in histones. So we have to sacrifice that.
